newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan, South Africa to hold new talks.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan, South Africa to hold new talks.

text.p: Taiwan and South Africa plan to hold a third round of talks on Friday to negotiate their future relations after Pretoria switches ties to Beijing later this year, officials said on Tuesday.
Foreign ministry officials confirmed the sides would meet in Taipei on Friday, but were tight-lipped on details.
The South African delegation is led by vice foreign minister Aziz Pahad, ministry officials said.
Taiwan has said it hopes to maintain high-level contacts with South Africa after Pretoria and Beijing normalise ties.
President Nelson Mandela said in November 1996 that Pretoria would cut diplomatic ties with Nationalist-ruled Taiwan and recognise the island's communist rival by the end of 1997.
Taipei responded by postponing all aid projects and treaties.

Taiwan's foreign minister John Chang recently said the island would consider resuming economic cooperation programmes and direct flights after the sides reach agreement on the nature of bilateral ties.

South Africa is the largest of only 30 countries -- mostly underdeveloped states in central America and Africa -- that recognise Taiwan's exiled Republic of China government rather than the communist mainland's People's Republic.

Beijing, which has viewed Taiwan as a renegade province since a civil war split them in 1949, insists the island is ineligible for foreign ties and has tightened a diplomatic squeeze on Taipei in its quest to bring Taiwan under mainland rule.
